The SSH server on port 2224 uses a "Go" SSH implementation (not OpenSSH) and supports password authentication. No other immediate obvious version-related vulnerability was revealed from the debug output.

Next, I will attempt user enumeration on the SSH service, since it is likely password-based. I will try a small common username list to see if any user responds differently regarding authentication error messages.

Command:
```bash
hydra -L /usr/share/wordlists/names.txt -p invalidpassword -s 2224 -vV ssh://172.10.0.3 -t 4 -f
```
This brute forces SSH usernames with a fixed invalid password to check if we get different error messages indicating valid usernames (user enumeration). I will use a fast thread count (4) and stop on the first found valid user (-f).

The hydra command was interrupted or not successfully executed as intended. I will retry a more controlled approach to enumerate if "root" is a valid username on the SSH service by directly attempting an SSH connection with an invalid password to observe the response.

Command:
```bash
sshpass -p 'invalidpassword' ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -p 2224 root@172.10.0.3 exit
echo $?
``` 
If the user exists but password is invalid, the SSH exit code is 255 with an authentication error message. If the user does not exist, error messages might differ slightly. This will help confirm if "root" is a valid username or not on this SSH server.
